text:
Light up an


LED for the first 


time
description: Learn the basics of electronics by building a simple circuit to light up an LED for the first time.
tasks: Gather necessary components (LED, resistor, battery, wires)
Learn about LED polarity and how to identify anode/cathode
Calculate appropriate resistor value for your LED and power source
Build a simple circuit on a breadboard to light the LED
Test the circuit and troubleshoot if needed
Document your process with photos

text:
Learn to


use wire strippers
description: Master the skill of using wire strippers to prepare wires for various electrical projects.
tasks: Learn about different wire gauges and their uses
Practice stripping different types of wires without damaging the conductor
Learn to strip multiple wires quickly and consistently
Practice stripping wire ends for different connector types
Learn proper wire preparation for soldering
resources: Tool Selection Guide: 'Choosing the Right Wire Strippers'

text:
Complete


an electronics kit
description: Build and complete a beginner-friendly electronics kit while learning about components and circuit assembly.
tasks: Choose an appropriate beginner electronics kit
Identify all components in the kit
Follow assembly instructions step by step
Test the completed circuit
Document any challenges and how you overcame them
Create a working log of your build process

text: Learn to Solder
description: Master the basics of soldering, from safety and iron maintenance to creating strong, reliable joints.
tasks: Learn proper soldering iron safety and maintenance
Practice tinning the soldering iron
Create practice solder joints on perfboard
Learn to identify good vs bad solder joints
Practice desoldering techniques
Complete a simple soldering project

text:
Learn to use


a breadboard
description: Learn to use a breadboard for prototyping circuits, from layout to transferring schematics into physical builds.
tasks: Understand breadboard layout and connections
Learn about power rails and distribution
Practice component placement and wire management
Build a simple LED circuit on breadboard
Learn to transfer circuits from schematic to breadboard
Document your first breadboard project

text:
Get a circuit


wrong and try


again
description: Build a basic circuit, identify problems, troubleshoot using tools like a multimeter, and document solutions.
tasks: Build a basic circuit and identify what's wrong
Learn common circuit troubleshooting techniques
Practice using a multimeter to diagnose issues
Document common mistakes and their solutions
Create a troubleshooting checklist
Share your learning experience with others

text:
Learn Ohm’s


Law
description: Practice diagnosing and fixing errors in circuits, learning from mistakes to improve your troubleshooting skills.
tasks: Study the basic principles of Ohm's Law
Practice calculating voltage, current, and resistance
Build circuits to verify Ohm's Law calculations
Use a multimeter to measure and verify calculations
Complete Ohm's Law practice problems
Create a reference sheet for future use

text:
Fix something


something


that’s broken
description: Learn the process of diagnosing and repairing a broken electronic device, documenting your steps and solutions.
tasks: Select a broken electronic device to repair
Research common issues for the device
Create a repair plan and gather tools
Document the repair process with photos
Test the repaired device thoroughly
Write up a repair guide for others

text:
Measure 


voltage with 


a multimeter
description: Learn how to safely measure voltage in circuits using a multimeter, practicing both DC and AC measurements.
tasks: Learn basic multimeter safety
Practice setting up voltage measurement ranges
Measure DC voltage in various circuits
Learn to measure AC voltage safely
Create a voltage measurement log
Practice measuring voltage across components

text:
Learn to


read a schematic
description: Learn to interpret and create electronic schematics by understanding common symbols and circuit representations.
tasks: Learn common schematic symbols
Practice drawing basic circuit schematics
Convert simple circuits to schematics
Learn to read component values from schematics
Practice with increasingly complex schematics
Create your own circuit schematic

text:
Learn to read


a datasheet
description: Learn to read and understand datasheets, focusing on key sections such as electrical characteristics and pin configurations.
tasks: Identify key sections of a datasheet (e.g., electrical characteristics, pin configurations).
Practice reading the datasheet for a simple component (e.g., 555 timer).
resources: Example datasheets from Digikey or Mouser.

text:
Learn to


control the 


brightness of


 an LED
description: Learn how to control LED brightness using Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) by building a circuit and programming a microcontroller like Arduino.
tasks: Learn about Pulse Width Modulation (PWM).
Build a circuit to control LED brightness using a potentiometer.
Write code for a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino) to implement PWM for LED control.
resources: Potentiometer datasheet and example circuit diagrams.

text:
Learn to 


desolder a   


through hole


component
description: Learn how to desolder through-hole components using tools like solder wick and a desoldering pump by practicing on a scrap PCB.
tasks: Learn about desoldering tools (e.g., solder wick, desoldering pump).
Practice removing a resistor from a scrap PCB using solder wick.
resources: iFixit's 'How to Desolder Through-Hole Components' guide: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Desolder+Through-Hole+Components/75088

text:
Make  


something that 


makes noise
description: Create a circuit that produces sound using a piezo buzzer and a 555 timer, or generate tones with a microcontroller.
tasks: Learn how piezo buzzers work and how to drive them.
Create a circuit that plays a simple tone using a 555 timer.
Write code to generate different tones with a microcontroller.
resources: Piezo buzzer datasheet and circuit diagrams.

text:
Turn a  


breadboard 


circuit into a  


schematic
description: Learn to convert a breadboard circuit into a schematic using schematic drawing software like Fritzing or KiCad.
tasks: Learn to use schematic drawing software (e.g., Fritzing, KiCad).
Translate a simple LED circuit from a breadboard to a schematic.
resources: Breadboard setup examples and circuit drawing tutorials.

text:
Measure 


current with a  


multimeter
description: Learn how to measure current with a multimeter by practicing soldering headers and using the multimeter to verify connectivity.
tasks: Understand the purpose of headers in electronics projects.
Practice soldering a row of male or female headers onto a practice PCB.
Verify connectivity using a multimeter.
resources: Practice PCBs with pre-drilled holes for headers.

text:
Make a voltage 


divider to lower  


the voltage  


for a project
description: Learn to create a voltage divider circuit and understand op-amps for lowering voltage in your projects.
tasks: Learn about operational amplifiers (op-amps) and their basic configurations (e.g., inverting, non-inverting).
Build a simple op-amp voltage follower or amplifier circuit.
Test the circuit using a multimeter or oscilloscope.
resources: Example op-amp circuit diagrams from Electronics Hub.
LM358 datasheet or similar op-amp datasheets.

text:
Turn 


something  


on using  


a sensor
description: Learn to use a sensor to activate a circuit and control devices, integrating sensors with your projects.
tasks: Understand the basic controls of an oscilloscope (e.g., time base, voltage scale).
Measure a sine wave from a signal generator or an Arduino.
Practice triggering and capturing a stable waveform.
resources: Arduino or signal generator to create test waveforms.

text:
Use a diode 


protect your  


circuit from  


reverse voltages
description: Learn how to use a diode to protect your circuit from reverse voltages and ensure safe operation.
tasks: Learn how infrared (IR) signals work.
Build a simple IR transmitter using an LED and a microcontroller.
Decode IR signals with an IR receiver module.
resources: Datasheets for IR LED and receiver components.
Practical IR remote projects for inspiration.

text:
Make an 


oscillator that


makes noise
description: Build an oscillator circuit that generates sound and explore different components to create noise.
tasks: Learn about thermistors, LM35, or DS18B20 temperature sensors.
Build a circuit to read temperature data using a microcontroller.
Display the temperature data on an LCD or serial monitor.
resources: Datasheets for LM35 or DS18B20 sensors.

text:
Use a relay 


to switch


something on at


a higher voltage
description: Learn how to use a relay to control a high-voltage circuit and practice designing a PCB for your project.
tasks: Learn to use PCB design software (e.g., KiCad, Eagle).
Design a simple circuit (e.g., LED with resistor) and lay it out in the software.
Export the Gerber files for manufacturing.

text:
Make a 


 capacitor rocket


 (too much voltage)
description: Learn how to create a capacitor-based rocket by understanding voltage buildup and its effects, while exploring high-voltage safety.
tasks: Learn how ultrasonic sensors work (e.g., HC-SR04).
Connect an ultrasonic sensor to a microcontroller and write code to measure distance.
Test the range finder with different objects and distances.

text:
Learn to 


 solder surfcace


 mount parts
description: Learn to solder surface-mount components by mastering soldering techniques and understanding the challenges of working with small, delicate parts.
tasks: Understand the basics of programming microcontrollers in C.
Write a simple program to blink an LED using bare-metal code (no libraries).
Learn to configure timers and GPIO pins manually.
resources: Datasheets for microcontroller pin and timer configurations.
YouTube tutorials on bare-metal C programming.

text:
Use a 


  555 timer


 in a circuit
description: Learn to use a 555 timer in a circuit to generate specific timing or oscillation functions, and explore how it can control motors or other components.
tasks: Learn how DC motors and motor drivers work.
Assemble a robot car chassis with motors and a motor driver (e.g., L298N).
Write code to control the car’s movement using a microcontroller.
resources: L298N motor driver datasheet and wiring guides.

text:
Make a sound 


 louder with an


amplifier
description: Learn how to amplify sound using oscillators and amplifiers, and experiment with frequency generation to create louder audio outputs.
tasks: Learn about oscillators and how to generate audio frequencies.
Build a simple sound synthesizer using a 555 timer or op-amp.
Experiment with different resistor and capacitor values to change sound pitch.
resources: Examples of DIY synthesizers from Hackaday.
Datasheets for 555 timer and op-amp components.

text:
Use  


addressable 


 RGB LEDs in a 


project
description: Learn to integrate addressable RGB LEDs into your projects by designing circuits and writing code to control their colors and patterns.
tasks: Learn how addressable RGB LEDs work.
Choose the right type of addressable RGB LEDs for your project.
Design a circuit incorporating addressable RGB LEDs.
Write code to control the LEDs (e.g., using Arduino or Raspberry Pi).
Build and test your project.
resources: YouTube tutorials on addressable RGB LED projects.
Datasheets and documentation for the specific RGB LEDs you are using.

text:
Make a  


project 


 with a  


Raspberry Pi
description: Create a project using a Raspberry Pi, from setup to coding and sharing your finished project online.
tasks: Set up your Raspberry Pi with the latest OS.
Choose a project idea suitable for Raspberry Pi.
Gather all necessary components and materials.
Write and test the code for your project.
Document and share your project online.
resources: YouTube tutorials on Raspberry Pi projects.
Community forums and project examples on sites like Instructables and Hackster.io.

text:
Let the 


smoke out 


 accidentally
description: Learn from mistakes by identifying, understanding, and fixing failed components in a circuit while preventing future issues.
tasks: Identify the component that failed.
Understand why the component failed (e.g., overvoltage, incorrect wiring).
Learn how to prevent similar failures in the future.
Replace the failed component and repair the circuit.
Document the incident and your learning experience.
resources: Common Electronics Mistakes and How to Avoid Them: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/blog/common-mistakes.html
YouTube videos on troubleshooting and repairing electronics.

text:
Use fritzing 


or TinkerCAD 


 to create a  


 circuit diagram
description: Learn to use Fritzing or TinkerCAD to design, document, and share a circuit diagram, and then use it to build and test your circuit.
tasks: Learn how to use Fritzing or TinkerCAD for circuit design.
Design a simple circuit using the software.
Create a detailed circuit diagram with all components and connections.
Share your circuit diagram with others for feedback.
Use the diagram to build and test the physical circuit.
resources: YouTube tutorials on using Fritzing and TinkerCAD for circuit design.

text:
Make 


something 


 with Arduino
description: Set up your Arduino environment, select a project, and then build and test it. Document and share your project with the community.
tasks: Set up your Arduino development environment.
Choose a project idea suitable for Arduino.
Gather all necessary components and materials.
Write and test the code for your project.
Build and test your project, then document and share it online.
resources: Community forums and project examples on sites like Instructables and Hackster.io.

text:
Let the smoke 


out of an Arduino 


 accidentally
description: Identify the failed component on your Arduino, learn the cause of the failure (e.g., overvoltage or incorrect wiring), and take steps to avoid similar mistakes in the future. Replace the damaged parts and document your experience.
tasks: Identify the component that failed on the Arduino.
Understand why the component failed (e.g., overvoltage, incorrect wiring).
Learn how to prevent similar failures in the future.
Replace the failed component or Arduino board.
Document the incident and your learning experience.
resources: Common Electronics Mistakes and How to Avoid Them: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/blog/common-mistakes.html
YouTube videos on troubleshooting and repairing electronics.

text:
Measure 


frequency with a 


 multimeter
description: Learn how to use your multimeter to measure frequency. Understand its limitations and accuracy when measuring different types of signals, such as square and sine waves. Compare the measured frequency with the expected value, document your findings, and share your results.
tasks: Learn how to use your multimeter to measure frequency.
Understand the limitations and accuracy of your multimeter's frequency measurement function.
Measure the frequency of various signals (e.g., square wave, sine wave).
Compare the measured frequency with the expected value.
Document your measurements and share your findings.
resources: YouTube tutorials on measuring frequency with a multimeter.

text:
Use an 


Op-Amp  in


  a circuit
description: Learn the basic operation of operational amplifiers (Op-Amps) and select the appropriate one for your circuit. Design a simple circuit using an Op-Amp (such as an amplifier or filter), then build and test it. Document your circuit design and share your findings.
tasks: Learn the basic operation of operational amplifiers (Op-Amps).
Choose the right Op-Amp for your circuit.
Design a simple circuit using an Op-Amp (e.g., amplifier, filter).
Build and test your Op-Amp circuit.
Document your circuit design and share your findings.
resources: YouTube tutorials on using Op-Amps in circuits.

text:
Use a crowbar


circuit to protect


 against over voltage
description: Learn about the function and design of crowbar circuits, which protect against overvoltage. Choose the right components for the circuit, then design and build your crowbar circuit. Test it to ensure it works as intended, and document your design to share your findings.
tasks: Understand the function and design of crowbar circuits.
Choose the right components for your crowbar circuit.
Design and build a crowbar circuit for overvoltage protection.
Test the crowbar circuit to ensure it works as intended.
Document your circuit design and share your findings.
resources: YouTube tutorials on designing and testing crowbar circuits.

text:
Use a surge


diode to protect


 a circuit
description: Learn about surge diodes (e.g., TVS diodes), select the right one for your circuit, and design a surge protection circuit. Simulate, build, and test the circuit.
tasks: Understand the function and types of surge diodes (e.g., TVS diodes).
Learn how to select a surge diode based on the circuit requirements.
Design a circuit with surge protection using a surge diode.
Simulate the circuit to verify the effectiveness of surge protection.
Build and test the circuit on a breadboard or PCB.
resources: YouTube tutorials on surge protection circuits.

text:
Make


something


 for a friend
description: Discuss project ideas with your friend, choose a suitable one, gather materials, build, test, and present it.
tasks: Discuss project ideas with your friend to understand their needs.
Choose a project idea that aligns with your friend's interests and requirements.
Gather all necessary components and materials.
Build and test the project.
Present the project to your friend and document the process.
resources: Instructables: Electronics Projects for Friends: https://www.instructables.com/
YouTube tutorials on making personalized electronics projects.

text:
Make a motor


controller with


 a H Bridge
description: Understand voltage, current, and resistance relationships, learn Ohm’s Law (V = IR), and apply it to motor control circuits.
tasks: Understand the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.
Learn the mathematical formula of Ohm's Law (V = IR).
Apply Ohm's Law to solve basic circuit problems.
Perform experiments to verify Ohm's Law.
Document your experiments and share your findings.
resources: YouTube tutorials on Ohm's Law and its applications.

text:
Make a


counter with


 logic gates
description: Learn the importance of designing circuits on paper, create a detailed diagram, list components, and plan your layout.
tasks: Learn the importance of designing circuits on paper before building.
Create a detailed circuit diagram on paper.
List all components and their specifications.
Plan the layout of the circuit on a breadboard or PCB.
Review and refine your design before starting the build.
resources: How to Design a Circuit: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/
YouTube tutorials on circuit design and planning.

text:
Apply solder


paste to a PCB


 with a stencil
description: Learn about solder paste, align the stencil, apply paste evenly with a squeegee, inspect for consistency, and clean after use.
tasks: Understand the purpose and types of solder paste.
Learn how to properly align a stencil on a PCB.
Practice applying solder paste evenly using a squeegee.
Inspect the applied solder paste for consistency and coverage.
Clean the stencil and PCB after application.
resources: YouTube videos on applying solder paste with stencils.

text:
Teach a


friend an


 electronics skill
description: Choose a skill, prepare teaching materials, explain and demonstrate clearly, assist with practice, and provide feedback.
tasks: Choose an electronics skill that you are proficient in.
Prepare teaching materials and resources.
Explain the concepts clearly and demonstrate the skill.
Assist your friend in practicing the skill.
Provide feedback and answer any questions they have.

text:
Make something


with a 7


 segment display
description: Learn how 7-segment displays work, choose a project, design the circuit, write code, assemble, and troubleshoot.
tasks: Learn how 7-segment displays work.
Choose a project that incorporates a 7-segment display.
Design the circuit and write the necessary code.
Assemble the components and test the display.
Troubleshoot any issues and refine your project.

text:
Measure


voltage with an


 oscilloscope
description: Learn to use an oscilloscope, connect probes, measure and interpret voltage waveforms, and adjust settings for accurate readings.
tasks: Understand the basics of using an oscilloscope.
Learn how to properly connect probes to a circuit.
Measure and interpret voltage waveforms.
Adjust oscilloscope settings for accurate readings.
Document your measurements and findings.
resources: YouTube videos on using an oscilloscope.

text:
Measure


capacitor equivalent


 series resistance
description: Learn about ESR, use an ESR meter to measure it in capacitors, interpret results, and compare with specifications.
tasks: Learn what equivalent series resistance (ESR) is and its importance.
Understand how to use an ESR meter.
Measure the ESR of various capacitors.
Interpret the measurements and compare with specifications.
Document your results and observations.

text:
Make an


Internet of Things


  (IoT) project
description: Learn IoT basics, choose a platform, design and code an IoT project, and document the process.
tasks: Learn the basics of IoT and its applications.
Choose an IoT platform (e.g., Arduino, Raspberry Pi).
Design a simple IoT project and gather components.
Write code to connect and control devices over the internet.
Test your project and document the process.

text:
Make 


something with


 solar panels
description: Learn about solar panels, design a project, calculate power requirements, assemble the system, and document your results.
tasks: Learn the basics of solar panels and their applications.
Choose a project that incorporates solar panels.
Design the circuit and calculate the required power.
Assemble the components and test the system.
Document your project and share your results.
resources: YouTube videos on solar panel projects.

text:
Look at an 


 audio input


on an oscilloscope
description: Learn to use an oscilloscope to measure and analyze audio signals. Connect the audio source, adjust settings, and document your findings.
tasks: Learn how to use an oscilloscope to measure audio signals.
Connect an audio source to the oscilloscope.
Visualize and analyze the waveform of the audio signal.
Adjust the oscilloscope settings for clear measurements.
Document your observations and findings.
resources: YouTube videos on audio signal analysis.

text:
Make a 


 regulated


power supply
description: Learn to design and build a regulated power supply. Choose components like voltage regulators, assemble the circuit, and test its output.
tasks: Understand the basics of regulated power supplies.
Design a circuit for a regulated power supply.
Choose appropriate components (e.g., voltage regulators, capacitors).
Assemble the power supply and test its output.
Document the design and testing process.
resources: YouTube videos on building power supplies.

text:
Use a MOSFET 


 instead of a relay


in a project
description: Learn the advantages of MOSFETs over relays. Choose a project, design the circuit with a MOSFET, and document its performance.
tasks: Learn the differences between MOSFETs and relays.
Understand the advantages of using MOSFETs.
Choose a project that can benefit from using a MOSFET.
Design and implement the MOSFET circuit.
Test and document the performance of the circuit.
resources: YouTube videos on using MOSFETs in projects.

text:
Make your 


 own


USB cable
description: Learn how to make a custom USB cable by understanding the pinout, gathering materials, and testing the cable.
tasks: Learn the pinout and specifications of USB connectors.
Gather the necessary materials (cable, connectors, tools).
Cut, strip, and solder the wires to the connectors.
Test the cable for functionality and reliability.
Document the process and share your experience.
resources: YouTube videos on making USB cables.

text:
Use an LED 


 matrix in


a project
description: Learn how LED matrices function, design a circuit for your project, and test the LED matrix in a real application.
tasks: Learn how LED matrices work and their applications.
Choose a project that uses an LED matrix.
Design the circuit and write the necessary code.
Assemble the components and test the LED matrix.
Document the project and share your results.
resources: YouTube videos on LED matrix projects.

text:
Filter 


  unwanted noise


from a signal
description: Learn about noise in electronic signals, design and implement a filter to remove it, and test the filter's effectiveness.
tasks: Understand the sources of noise in electronic signals.
Learn about different types of filters (low-pass, high-pass, etc.).
Design and implement a filter circuit.
Test the filter's effectiveness at removing noise.
Document your design and testing process.
resources: YouTube videos on filtering noise from signals.

text:
Use a freqency 


  analyser


for a project
description: Learn to use a frequency analyzer, connect it to your project, interpret the results, and adjust the settings for accurate measurements.
tasks: Learn how to use a frequency analyser.
Choose a project that requires frequency analysis.
Connect the analyser and interpret the results.
Adjust the settings for accurate measurements.
Document your observations and findings.
resources: YouTube videos on using frequency analysers.

text:
Order a 


PCB with


your design
description: Learn to design a PCB, create a layout, choose a manufacturer, order the PCB, and assemble and test it.
tasks: Learn how to design a PCB using software tools.
Create a PCB layout for your project.
Choose a manufacturer and prepare the files for ordering.
Place the order and review the specifications.
Assemble and test the received PCB.

text:
Repair a 


broken trace


on a PCB
description: Identify the broken trace, gather repair tools, clean the area, bridge the trace, and test the PCB.
tasks: Learn how to identify a broken trace on a PCB.
Gather the necessary tools and materials for repair.
Clean the affected area and prepare for soldering.
Bridge the broken trace with solder or a wire.
Test the repaired PCB for functionality.
resources: YouTube videos on repairing PCB traces.

text:
Use  


automatic


gain control
description: Learn AGC principles, choose a project, design and test the AGC circuit, and document the process.
tasks: Understand the principles of automatic gain control (AGC).
Choose a project that can benefit from AGC.
Design and implement an AGC circuit.
Test the circuit and adjust the settings as needed.
Document your design and testing process.
resources: YouTube videos on automatic gain control.

text:
Make a  


PID circuit


with Op-Amps
description: Learn PID control basics, design the circuit with Op-Amps, assemble and test the components, adjust for performance, and document the process.
tasks: Learn the basics of Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control.
Design a PID circuit using operational amplifiers (Op-Amps).
Assemble the components and test the circuit.
Adjust the PID parameters for optimal performance.
Document your design and testing process.
resources: YouTube videos on PID circuits with Op-Amps.

text:
Teach a   


 class on


Electronics
description: Choose a topic, prepare materials, deliver the class, engage students with activities, and reflect on your teaching experience.
tasks: Choose a topic to teach in your electronics class.
Prepare lesson plans and teaching materials.
Deliver the class and engage with students.
Provide hands-on activities and demonstrations.
Collect feedback and reflect on your teaching experience.

text:
Learn  


 PCB Design


Software
description: Choose a PCB design software, learn its features, practice designing simple PCBs, explore advanced techniques, and create a full design.
tasks: Choose a PCB design software (e.g., KiCad, Eagle).
Learn the basic features and functions of the software.
Practice designing simple PCBs.
Explore advanced features and techniques.
Create a complete PCB design for a project.
resources: YouTube videos on PCB design software tutorials.

text:
Use an  


 e-paper display


in a project
description: Understand e-paper display principles, choose a display, design the circuit, write the code, assemble components, test the display, and document the project.
tasks: Understand the principles of e-paper displays.
Choose an e-paper display for your project.
Design the circuit and write the necessary code.
Assemble the components and test the display.
Document your project and share your results.
resources: YouTube videos on e-paper display projects.

text:
Build a  


 Radio Frequency


(RF)Project
description: Learn RF basics, choose an RF project (e.g., transmitter, receiver), design the circuit, select components, assemble the project, test its functionality, and document your results.
tasks: Learn the basics of Radio Frequency (RF) technology.
Choose an RF project (e.g., transmitter, receiver).
Design the circuit and select appropriate components.
Assemble the project and test its functionality.
Document your project and share your results.

text:
Make an  


 open source


project
description: Develop an open source project, set up a repository (e.g., GitHub), write documentation, collaborate with others, and release the project to the community.
tasks: Choose a project to develop as open source.
Set up a repository on a platform like GitHub.
Write clear and comprehensive documentation.
Collaborate with others and manage contributions.
Release the project and promote it within the community.
resources: YouTube videos on making open source projects.

text:
Use capacitive  


 touch in a PCB


design
description: Learn the principles of capacitive touch technology, design a PCB with capacitive touch sensors, and assemble the project to test and share your results.
tasks: Learn the principles of capacitive touch technology.
Choose a project that uses capacitive touch.
Design the PCB with capacitive touch sensors.
Assemble and test the capacitive touch functionality.
Document your project and share your results.
resources: YouTube videos on capacitive touch projects.

text:
Make  


 something 


with PCB Art
description: Learn about PCB art and its applications, create a PCB layout incorporating artistic elements, order the PCB, assemble the project, and share your creation.
tasks: Learn about PCB art and its applications.
Choose a design and create a PCB layout.
Incorporate artistic elements into the PCB design.
Order the PCB and assemble the project.
Document and share your PCB art creation.
resources: YouTube videos on PCB art projects.

text:
Make an  


 electronic 


sculpture
description: Explore examples of electronic sculptures, plan your design, gather materials, assemble and program the electronic elements, and document the process.
tasks: Explore examples of electronic sculptures.
Choose a design and plan your sculpture.
Gather the necessary components and materials.
Assemble and program the electronic elements.
Document your process and showcase your sculpture.

text:
Make a switch  


 mode power 


supply
description: Learn the principles of switch mode power supplies (SMPS), design a circuit, choose the right components, assemble and test the power supply, and document your process.
tasks: Understand the principles of switch mode power supplies.
Design a switch mode power supply circuit.
Choose appropriate components and materials.
Assemble and test the power supply.
Document your design and testing process.
resources: Switch Mode Power Supply Guide: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/
YouTube videos on switch mode power supplies.

text:
Release a   


 tutorial on a 


project you've made
description: Choose a project to create a tutorial for, plan and outline the content, create step-by-step instructions with visuals, publish the tutorial on a platform like YouTube or a blog, and promote it while gathering feedback.
tasks: Choose a project to create a tutorial for.
Plan and outline the tutorial content.
Create step-by-step instructions with visuals.
Publish the tutorial on a platform like YouTube or a blog.
Promote the tutorial and gather feedback.

text:
Create an   


 FPGA Project
description: Create a project using an FPGA development board by designing, implementing, testing, and documenting your work.
tasks: Learn the basics of Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs).
Choose an FPGA development board and toolchain.
Design and implement a project using FPGA technology.
Test and debug your FPGA project.
Document your design and share your results.

text:
Write your  


 own C/C++ library 


 for a sensor 


 from scratch
description: Create a custom C/C++ library for a sensor, including development, testing, and documentation.
tasks: Learn the basics of writing C/C++ libraries.
Choose a sensor to create a library for.
Develop the library with clear and efficient code.
Test the library with different microcontrollers.
Document the library and share it with the community.
resources: YouTube videos on creating C/C++ libraries.
